div.sent: Measurement is an essential element in learning science.
Measurement is required to know the exact figure of a certain length, weight or time.
We need to measure things in various ways in our day to day life.
We often have to take measurementssometimes of small things, sometimes of larger items.
Different types of measurements require different types of instruments as well as methods.
The balance used for measuring gold is different from the balance used for measuring rice or pulse.
Again, the measurement of gold requires much more accuracy than that of rice or pulse.
In this chapter we will discuss only how to measure the length with accuracy and precision.
In day-to-day life we use various types of things such as pin, needle, wire, lock and key etc.
Needles of different sizes are required in sewing machines and in injection syringes.
If the size of the needle is not correct, it can not be used in the machine or with the injection syringe.
To open a lock a key of the proper size is needed, any key will not do.
In order to make these things precise and correct, measurement is required.
Similarly, things like radio, television, watch, bi-cycle, motor-car etc have many small parts in them.
If these parts are not of accurate size, they may not fit in properly.
Therefore, precise and correct measurement is needed to assemble these things.
Precise and correct measurement is required in many scientific operations.
Say, you are to measure the coefficient of linear expansion of iron, which is 0.000012/C.
That is, a one metre long iron rod will have 1.2 mm expansion if its temperature is raised by 100C.
In case of nickel this expansion will be 1.3 mm; i.e. the difference is only 0.1mm.
Therefore, correct and accurate measurement is required in order to determine the linear expansions of iron and nickel and to differentiate between them precisely.
The smallest unit of an ordinary metre scale is 1mm.
This scale cannot be used to measure any length smaller than 1mm.
Pierre Vernier, a Belgian mathematician, devised a special kind of scale to measure lengths very precisely.
This scale is called vernier scale after his name.
Vernier scale is small in length (fig.
It is attached to the main scale in a way that it can slide along towards left and right.
Vernier scale is generally divided into ten equal divisions and its length is equal to the nine divisions of the main scale.
That is, 1 division of vernier scale= 9/10 mm =0.9 mm.
The difference between one main scale division and one vernier scale division is known as vernier constant.

Therefore the vernier scale whose vernier constant is 0.1 mm measures a length of 0.01 mm accurately.
An ordinary metre scale can measure lengths upto 1mm accurately.
Whereas, fractions of 1mm length can be measured accurately by vernier scale.
For example, the length of a rod is to be measured (Fig-7.2).
Shift the vernier scale towards right and place the rod along the length of the main scale.
Coincide the left end of the rod with the zero of the main scale.
Now move the vernier scale to bring it to the other end of the rod.
Take the main scale reading just before the zero of the vernier.
This is the main scale reading.
Now mark which of the vernier division coincides with or nearly in coincidence with the main scale division.
Count this vernier scale division starting from zero.
This is the vernier reading for the length of the rod.
Actually, vernier scale reading indicates how much the vernier scale is ahead of the main scale reading.
Here, it is 0.4 mm or 0.04 cm ahead of the main scale reading 3.6 cm.
Slide callipers is a special type of vernier scale.
Its principle of measurement is the same but it is different in structure.
The main scale of this instrument is made of steel.
A fixed steel jaw is the zero of the main scale.
The fixed jaw is at rigt angle to the length of the main scale.
Another steel jaw, to which vernier scale is attached, slides over the main scale.
This sliding vernier scale can be fixed at any desired place with a screw (F).
There is a narrow steel rod (R) fixed to vernier scale on its back and along the main scale.
In this position the zero mark of the vernier scale coincides with the zero mark of the main scale.
Now readings of the main scale and vernier scale are taken and their sum will give the apparent length of the body.
When the two jaws of vernier scale and main scale touch each other, the zeroes of the two scales should coincide.
If they do not coincide, there is error in the instrument.
The error is called instrumental error.
In such case the apparent length is to be corrected.
Positive error makes the apparent length more then the actual length and negative error makes it less.
So, to get the real length, instrumental error is to be subtracted from the apparent length.
To determine instrumental error, the two jaws are made to touch each other.
In this condition the reading of the vernier scale, which is in coincidence with the main scale division, is taken.
This reading is multiplied by the vernier constant to calculate the instrumental error.

Place the body touching the fixed jaw.
Now slide the other jaw and make it touch the other side of the body.
The two jaws are now touching the two sides of the body.
Screw it firmly.Take the main scale reading and vernier scale reading now.
This time the upper parts of the jaws are entered into the hollow cylinder.
Unscrew the vernier scale and move the sliding jaws until the two jaws touch the two opposite walls of the cylinder along the diameter.
Now screw the vernier and take readings of the two scales.
